bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, June 18, 1934

div1.p: Kean thanks Moran for sending him his immunity certificate signed by the Yellow Fever Board members. Kean comments on the political situation in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, June 18, 1934
div1.opener:

FIFTH VICE-PRESIDENT

UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
18 June, 1934.
Mr. J. J. Moran,
Avenida Menocãl No. 102-A,
Havana, Cuba.
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I was much pleased to get your letter enclosing your
immune certificate signed by the members of the Yellow Fever Board.
It is really an historical document, and I have turned it over to
Major Hume, the officer in charge of the Army Medical Library. The
Surgeon General is away on an inspection trip but when he returns he
will write you a personal letter of thanks. I think Major Hume also
will send you a photostat copy of the certificate.

It was a great pleasure to know that you and my good friend
Dr. Peña had gotten together. Peña is the salt of the earth and is
the only man in Cuba with whom I have kept constantly in touch during
all these years. I was glad to know that you and he think the horizon
looks brighter for Cuba. The news in the morning paper of desperadoes
opening fire on a procession with a machine gun is most discouraging.
I was glad to see that they were promptly killed.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Brig. Gen. U.S. Army, Ret.
